channel.title: NYT > Business
channel.copyright: Copyright 2026 The New York Times Company

item.title: Nicolai Tangen Manages Trillions of Dollars, but His Podcast Made Him Famous
item.description: Nicolai Tangen wanted to raise the profile of Norway’s $2.1 trillion oil fund and change corporate behavior, but he may have helped embroil it in a geopolitical tangle.
item.dc:creator: Ravi Mattu
item.media:credit: David B. Torch for The New York Times
item.media:description: Nicolai Tangen is the chief executive of Norges Bank Investment Management, which manages Norway’s sovereign wealth fund.

item.title: Trump Orders Fannie and Freddie to Buy $200 Billion in Mortgage Bonds
item.description: The move, a bid to make homes more affordable, would be a back-to-future moment for the two mortgage firms. Buying risky mortgage bonds helped push them to near-bankruptcy in 2008.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Goldstein and Joe Rennison
item.category: Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp (Freddie Mac)
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump has raised a number of ideas to lower housing costs, part of an effort by the White House to show it is responding to the public’s concerns about the affordability of housing.

item.title: G.M. Books a $7.1 Billion Loss as It Scales Back E.V. Ambitions
item.description: General Motors said it was writing down the value of battery and electric vehicle factories after changes in federal policy undercut demand.
item.dc:creator: Jack Ewing
item.media:credit: Brett Carlsen for The New York Times
item.media:description: Battery assembly at a General Motors facility in Spring Hill, Tenn. Electric cars have become more difficult to sell since the elimination of federal tax credits last year.

item.title: Polymarket Won’t Pay Users Who Bet on a U.S. Invasion of Venezuela
item.description: Polymarket users bet on whether the U.S. would invade Venezuela, but the prediction market said the Venezuelan president’s capture did not constitute an invasion.
item.dc:creator: Joe Rennison
item.media:credit: Vincent Alban/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Nicolás Maduro of Venezuela and his wife were brought to New York after they were captured by U.S. Special Forces.

item.title: Democratic lawmakers ask for an investigation of the Middle East envoy Steve Witkoff.
item.description: The request by a group of Congress members cites reporting by The Times and echoes a similar request by Democratic senators in September.
item.dc:creator: David Yaffe-Bellany
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: Steve Witkoff, the White House’s Middle East envoy, went into business with President Trump weeks before the 2024 election, unveiling a crypto company called World Liberty Financial that would be run by their sons.

item.title: U.S. Trade Deficit Fell to Lowest Level Since 2009 as Tariffs Reshape Trade
item.description: The monthly trade deficit continued to shrink in October after President Trump imposed sweeping tariffs on imports, the latest data showed.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson
item.media:credit: The New York Times

item.title: The (Many) Wrinkles in Trump’s Vision for Venezuela
item.description: President Trump appears committed to laying claim to Venezuelan oil for a long time. But there are plenty of reasons for U.S. businesses to be wary.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Ross Sorkin, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Niko Gallogly, Brian O’Keefe and Vivienne Walt
item.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump has said the U.S. should exert more control over Venezuela’s oil industry.

item.title: China Is Investigating Meta’s Acquisition of the AI Start-Ip Manus
item.description: Regulators said they would look at whether the deal for Manus, a Singapore start-up with Chinese roots, complied with China’s export and investment rules.
item.dc:creator: Meaghan Tobin, Xinyun Wu and Eli Tan
item.media:credit: Jason Henry for The New York Times
item.media:description: Meta’s deal for Manus last month capped a year of extravagant spending by the American company on elite artificial intelligence researchers.

item.title: Minimum Wage Rises in Some States as Workers Struggle With Basic Costs
item.description: This year, for the first time, more Americans will earn a minimum wage of $15 per hour or higher than will earn the federal minimum of $7.25 per hour.
item.dc:creator: Audra D. S. Burch
item.media:credit: Win McNamee/Getty Images
item.media:description: A sign at a Raise the Wage Act rally on the National Mall in March 2021.

item.title: Push to Audit Private Equity and Venture Capital Falters Under Trump
item.description: Specialists have left the I.R.S. and audits have been abandoned since the president returned to office.
item.dc:creator: Jesse Drucker
item.media:credit: Chris W. Kim

item.title: Mamdani Hosts Influencer Summit, Sidestepping Traditional Media
item.description: A friendly summit at New York’s City Hall with digital content creators and social media stars symbolized the new mayor’s attitude toward the changing news media.
item.dc:creator: Michael M. Grynbaum

item.title: Google and Character.AI to Settle Lawsuit Over Teenager’s Death
item.description: The settlement came in the case of a 14-year-old in Florida who had killed himself after developing a relationship with an A.I. chatbot.
item.dc:creator: Natallie Rocha
item.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times
item.media:description: Megan L. Garcia holds her phone with an image of her son Sewell Setzer III, who killed himself after conversing with an A.I. chatbot from the company Character.AI.

item.title: Trump Says He Wants Congress to Stop Wall St. From Buying Single-Family Houses
item.description: The president said he wanted Congress to stop the purchases by big investors, which have driven up rents and set obstacles for first-time buyers in some markets.
item.dc:creator: Maureen Farrell and Matthew Goldstein
item.media:credit: Jeenah Moon/Reuters
item.media:description: Blackstone, the huge private equity firm, is among the largest operators of single-family home rentals that could be affected by the president’s demand.

item.title: Pittsburgh Post-Gazette Announces It Will Cease Operations
item.description: The family-owned company that operates the newspaper cited mounting losses and labor constraints. A final edition is expected on Sunday, May 3.
item.dc:creator: Mark Walker and Emmett Lindner
item.media:credit: Maddie McGarvey for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Pittsburgh Post-Gazette’s owner, Block Communications, said the newspaper will cease publication in May.

item.title: Bruce Crawford, Arts-Loving Adman Who Led the Met Opera, Dies at 96
item.description: He helped build the ad agency BBDO International into a powerhouse before channeling his passion for opera into managing the Met and revitalizing Lincoln Center.
item.dc:creator: Robert D. McFadden
item.category: Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts
item.media:credit: Larry Sillen/Lincoln Center, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Bruce Crawford in 2005 after announcing he would step down as chairman of Lincoln Center.

item.title: How The Times Is Drawing on Over a Century of Reporting in Venezuela
item.description: The New York Times has been on the ground in the country since at least the 1880s, through celebration, suffering and political turmoil.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Bahr
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario/Corbis Saba, for The New York Times
item.media:description: The New York Times has made on-the-ground reporting in Venezuela a priority for more than a century. Above, a demonstration against Hugo Chávez in 2002.

item.title: Trump Deepens Scrutiny of Minnesota, a Potential Model for Other Blue States
item.description: The White House is intensifying and broadening its probes into fraud in states led by prominent Democrats.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport
item.media:credit: Jamie Kelter Davis for The New York Times
item.media:description: Federal agents executed a search warrant as part of a fraud investigation in Bloomington, Minn., last month.

item.title: Oil Firms Say Venezuela Owes Them Billions Over Earlier Investments
item.description: Companies like Exxon Mobil and ConocoPhillips say that Venezuela owes them billions of dollars for confiscating their assets two decades ago.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Penn
item.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
item.media:description: A tanker docked near a refinery in Punto Fijo, Venezuela. The cost of restoring the country’s oil production after decades of decline is expected to be substantial.

item.title: Alaska Airlines to Buy 110 Boeing Planes as It Seeks to Expand
item.description: Alaska’s order, its largest ever, follows its acquisition of Hawaiian Airlines and is part of its plan to expand, including overseas.
item.dc:creator: Niraj Chokshi
item.category: Boeing 737 Max Groundings and Safety Concerns (2019)
item.media:credit: M. Scott Brauer for The New York Times
item.media:description: For Alaska Airlines, which has a strong following on the West Coast, the deal will help fulfill its plans to grow.

item.title: U.S. Details Plan for Venezuela’s Oil Sales After Trump Claims Millions of Barrels
item.description: The Trump administration said it had an agreement with Venezuela’s government, but the country’s state-owned oil company said negotiations were underway.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca F. Elliott and Robert Jimison
item.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
item.media:description: An oil refinery in Punto Fijo, Venezuela. President Trump said late Tuesday that Venezuela would soon send 30 million to 50 million barrels of oil to the United States.

item.title: Why Trump’s Greenland Strategy Has the World on Edge
item.description: The president is again focused on acquiring the mineral-rich island. But lack of clarity about his goals and tactics is weighing on political and business leaders.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Ross Sorkin, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Niko Gallogly and Brian O’Keefe
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Marko Djurica/Reuters
item.media:description: President Trump’s desire for Greenland has put allies at home and abroad on edge.

item.title: Warner Bros. Board Rebuffs Paramount’s Latest Buyout Offer
item.description: The board said the blockbuster deal it reached with Netflix last month posed less risk.
item.dc:creator: Lauren Hirsch
item.media:credit: Philip Cheung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Warner Bros. Discovery, which agreed last month to sell most of its business to Netflix, advised its shareholders on Wednesday to reject Paramount’s latest rival bid.

item.title: China’s Threat to Block Rare Earths Has Put Japan on High Alert
item.description: Tokyo is concerned at signs that Beijing may be laying the groundwork to restrict access to the metals vital to manufacturing.
item.dc:creator: River Akira Davis
item.media:credit: Keith Bradsher/The New York Times
item.media:description: A truck hauling material out of a mining valley for heavy rare earth metals on the outskirts of Longnan, China, in April.

item.title: Fed’s Independence Faces Critical Tests as Trump Seeks to Remake Institution
item.description: The central bank faces two major hurdles early on in 2026 that will determine the extent to which it operates free of political meddling.
item.dc:creator: Colby Smith
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump has said anybody who disagrees with him will never get the top job at the Federal Reserve, prompting concern that his nominee will prioritize pleasing him over all else.

item.title: China Touts Hainan, Its Duty-Free Island, Amid $1 Trillion Trade Surplus
item.description: Policies meant to lure importers to Hainan, a resort island off China’s coast, signal an opening up, Beijing says. One expert calls it a “bait and switch.”
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrié for The New York Times
item.media:description: Visitors at an exhibition center promoting Hainan’s investment opportunities. The island is promoting itself as the world’s largest “free trade port.”

item.title: Hilton Drops Bookings for Minnesota Hotel Accused of Turning Away DHS Agents
item.description: The hotel giant said it took “immediate action” against a Hampton Inn near Minneapolis after a video showed a worker declining Department of Homeland Security reservations.
item.dc:creator: Christine Chung
item.media:credit: Google Maps
item.media:description: The Hampton Inn Lakeville Minneapolis, which is owned by a franchisee, no longer appears as a booking option on Hilton’s website.

item.title: Trump Claims Venezuela Will Send U.S. Millions of Barrels of Oil. Here’s What to Know.
item.description: It is unclear what, if anything, Venezuela would get in return for the oil, which is worth somewhere between $1.8 billion and $3 billion at current market prices.
item.dc:creator: Stanley Reed and Chris Cameron
item.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
item.media:description: An oil refinery in Punto Fijo, Venezuela. In November, the country’s oil production was estimated at 820,000 barrels a day.

item.title: Peter Zaffino, AIG’s Chief, Is Stepping Down in Latest Executive Reshuffling
item.description: The announcement that Peter Zaffino would step down as chief executive in June and become executive chairman sent the insurer’s stock tumbling.
item.dc:creator: Lauren Hirsch and Debra Kamin
item.media:credit: Andrew Redington/Getty Images
item.media:description: Peter Zaffino is widely credited with helping turn around AIG’s underwriting business.

item.title: Will Welch to Leave GQ After 7 Years as Its Top Editor
item.description: Mr. Welch worked to move the men’s magazine away from what he called “manly-man tropes.” His next role will be with Pharrell, the men’s designer of Louis Vuitton.
item.dc:creator: Jessica Testa
item.media:credit: Ike Edeani for The New York Times
item.media:description: Will Welch at the GQ offices in 2022.

item.title: The Rush to Profit From Maduro’s Capture
item.description: Trump administration officials are pushing American companies to quickly start investing in Venezuela. But energy giants have some major concerns.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Ross Sorkin, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Niko Gallogly, Brian O’Keefe, Ian Mount and Vivienne Walt
item.media:credit: Kaylee Greenlee/Reuters
item.media:description: Chevron is widely seen as a prime beneficiary of U.S. efforts to spur new investment in Venezuela — but it reportedly isn’t in a rush to expand there yet.

item.title: New York Times Case Against Pentagon Will Move Quickly
item.description: The lawsuit, over the Defense Department’s new rules for journalists, is headed for oral arguments in March.
item.dc:creator: Erik Wemple
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Lucia Vazquez for The New York Times
item.media:description: The New York Times has said restrictions imposed by the Pentagon in October infringe on the constitutional rights of journalists.

item.title: Victoria and Michael Wolff Document Their Lifestyle in ‘Our Amagansett House’
item.description: The author and Trump antagonist Michael Wolff has his wife, Victoria, to thank for his latest chapter: lifestyle influencer. Now she’s becoming one, too.
item.dc:creator: Rory Satran
item.media:credit: Justin Kaneps for The New York Times
item.media:description: Victoria Wolff, the writer of Our Amagansett House, a Substack newsletter, at the home she shares with her husband, Michael Wolff.

item.title: Optimism About Nuclear Energy Is Rising Again. Will It Last?
item.description: Companies like Kairos Power are building new types of reactors with the encouragement of the Trump administration, but their success is far from assured.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Penn
item.media:credit: Ramsay de Give for The New York Times
item.media:description: Kairos Power, which is developing a new kind of nuclear reactor, makes many of its parts at a facility in Albuquerque, N.M.

item.title: In China, a Debate About Political Power Ignites After Maduro’s Capture
item.description: The reactions online revealed a Chinese society divided: Some saw what happened in Venezuela as a playbook for seizing Taiwan, while others warned about ideological rigidity.
item.dc:creator: Li Yuan
item.media:credit: The New York Times
item.media:description: Supporters of Nicolás Maduro gathering near the Presidential Palace to demand his release.

item.title: Why Chevron Could Reap the Biggest Rewards From Venezuela
item.description: The second-largest U.S. oil company, which kept pumping oil in the country after others left, could find it relatively easy to expand its operations if the political conditions there improve.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca F. Elliott
item.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
item.media:description: A refinery in El Palito, Venezuela. Chevron is the only U.S. oil company with federal authorization to export oil from Venezuela.

item.title: Corporation for Public Broadcasting Votes to Shut Down
item.description: Executives debated whether to allow the corporation to lie dormant after federal funding ended last year, but decided against it.
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Mullin
item.media:credit: Daniel Rosenbaum for The New York Times
item.media:description: Patricia Harrison, president and chief executive of the Corporation for Public Broadcasting, in 2010. Congress last year voted to eliminate the organization’s $500 million in annual funding.

item.title: Caribbean Travelers Are Stranded After U.S. Raid in Venezuela Cancels Flights
item.description: Mass flight cancellations during peak holiday travel season have forced travelers to miss school and work and to spend thousands on extended tropical vacations.
item.dc:creator: Gabe Castro-Root
item.media:credit: Ricardo Arduengo/Reuters
item.media:description: Travelers were stuck at airports like Luis Muñoz Marín International near San Juan, P.R., after the United States closed some Caribbean airspace on Saturday during a raid to capture the president of Venezuela.

item.title: S&P 500’s Energy Sector Rises 2.7% on Investors’ Venezuela Bets
item.description: The energy sector of the S&P 500 rose 2.7 percent on Monday, lifting the broader market.
item.dc:creator: Joe Rennison

item.title: New Car Sales Are Rising Thanks to Purchases by the Well-Off
item.description: A larger proportion of new cars are being bought by affluent Americans as prices and interest rates for auto loans climb, analysts said.
item.dc:creator: Neal E. Boudette
item.media:credit: Saul Martinez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Wealthy consumers are keeping new car sales humming even as the auto industry battles tariffs, high interest rates and near-record prices.

item.title: How Nicolás Maduro’s Capture Could Reshape the Global Order
item.description: The U.S. seizure of Venezuela’s president has governments, executives and investors bracing for wide-reaching business and geopolitical fallout.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Ross Sorkin, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Niko Gallogly, Brian O’Keefe, Vivienne Walt and Lauren Hirsch
item.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Venezuela’s aging oil infrastructure has become a big investor focus after U.S. forces captured Nicolás Maduro this weekend.

item.title: China’s Oil Deal With Venezuela Faces Turning Point
item.description: Beijing has lent billions to Caracas in recent decades, and the fate of money it is owed is in question after the ouster of Venezuela’s leader.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Stevenson
item.media:credit: Peter Parks/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Hugo Chávez, then the leader of Venezuela, visiting Beijing in 2009.

item.title: Supreme Court Increasingly Favors the Rich, Economists Say
item.description: A new study found that the court’s Republican appointees voted for the wealthier side in cases 70 percent of the time in 2022, up from 45 percent in 1953.
item.dc:creator: Adam Liptak
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: The study concluded that the Supreme Court has become deeply polarized in cases pitting the rich against the poor.

item.title: Trump’s Goals for Reviving Venezuela’s Oil Industry Will Not Come Easily or Cheaply
item.description: It will take years and billions in investment to revitalize Venezuela’s oil industry, and energy producers will likely be cautious before stepping in.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca F. Elliott
item.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump wants U.S. oil companies back in Venezuela, which boasts the largest oil reserves in the world.

item.title: Jamie Dimon’s $770 Million Haul Shows How Bankers Are on Top Again
item.description: The Trump administration is lifting regulations, and deal making is heating up. For Jamie Dimon, being JPMorgan Chase’s chief executive was more lucrative in 2025 than ever.
item.dc:creator: Rob Copeland
item.category: Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jamie Dimon, the chief executive of JPMorgan Chase, often wields a spreadsheet that shows how heavily regulated banks like his are.

item.title: Travel Loyalty Programs Woo Fickle Customers With Members-Only Experiences
item.description: Travel loyalty programs are competing for customers with members-only experiences like backstage tours, exclusive dinners and access to V.I.P. areas.
item.dc:creator: Christine Chung and Amir Hamja
item.media:description: For under 10,000 points, Chase Sapphire Reserve card members can attend events like a roller-rink-themed party in New York last October with celebrities like Cher.

item.title: Behind the Scenes of Our Nicolás Maduro Front Page
item.description: After President Trump’s surprise ouster of Venezuela’s authoritarian leader, a team of New York Times editors set to work redoing the front page.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Bahr
item.media:credit: The New York Times

item.title: Colleen Keating, CEO of Planet Fitness, on Gen Z and Strength Training
item.description: Colleen Keating, chief executive of Planet Fitness, wants them to do it in a “judgment-free zone.”
item.dc:creator: Jordyn Holman
item.media:credit: Cody O'Loughlin for The New York Times
item.media:description: “We used to be a bit more cardio-forward, and now we’re dedicating about half the gym floor to strength and about half the club floor to cardio,” said Colleen Keating, chief executive of Planet Fitness.

item.title: Kevin O’Leary on ‘Marty Supreme’ and Notes He Gave Josh Safdie
item.description: When it came to his film acting debut, the“Shark Tank” investor had some notes for the director Josh Safdie.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Bahr
item.media:description: For the movie, O’Leary wore two watches, one on each wrist: one set to New York time, the other set to Tokyo time.

item.title: Airlines Are Canceling Flights After U.S. Closes Airspace Over the Caribbean
item.description: The Federal Aviation Administration cited “safety-of-flight risks” in restricting the U.S.-controlled airspace as a result of the military operation in Venezuela.
item.dc:creator: Mark Walker
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Joe Raedle/Getty Images
item.media:description: Several air carriers, including American Airlines, had canceled flights to destinations in the Caribbean early on Saturday.
